The energy and environmental crises are becoming increasingly severe. Syngas, derived from coal, oil, biomass and other materials as an important platform for the conversion of matter and energy, can converted to the higher alcohols. Higher alcohols are important industrial raw materials and transportation fuels. Therefore, the synthesis of higher alcohols from syngas can effectively alleviate the energy and environmental crises. Despite decades of research, it is regrettable that the syngas to higher alcohols is still in the experimental research stage and has not yet been industrialized. This review comprehensively introduces the current status and progress of Mo-based catalysts for the syngas to higher alcohols. It is divided into three parts: MoS2, Mo2C and other Mo-based catalysts (MoOx, MoP, Mo2N and MoSe2) applied in the syngas to higher alcohols. Each part includes the promoters (alkaline promoters and transition metal promoters), active phase of catalysts, support, the preparation method and catalytic mechanism. The structure-activity relationship of catalysts, catalyst preparation and catalytic mechanism are emphasized to highlight the recent progress and challenges of Mo-based catalysts. The purpose of this review is to provide a comprehensive summary of Mo-based catalysts for the syngas to higher alcohols to provide a reference for the design, development and future perspective of Mo-based catalysts. Graphical abstract Image, graphical abstract Keywords Syngas Higher alcohols MoS2 Mo2C Mo-based catalysts Data availability The authors are unable or have chosen not to specify which data has been used. 1 Introduction Direct synthesis of higher alcohols from syngas (HAS) can help alleviate the energy crisis [1] and greenhouse effect [2]. Syngas, typically a mixture of CO and H₂, is an excellent platform for material conversion and can be derived from a wide range of sources, including coal [3], heavy oil [4], natural gas [5], biomass [6], and CO₂ [7,8]. Converting CO₂ and green hydrogen into syngas in specific ratios can efficiently utilize CO₂ and mitigate the greenhouse effect. Higher alcohols (alcohols with two or more carbon atoms) can be used as transportation fuels and fundamental industrial raw materials, which can effectively address the energy crisis. Therefore, the HAS have garnered significant attention from researchers. HAS usually involves the dissociation and non-dissociation adsorption processes of CO, as shown in Fig. 1 . Dissociation adsorbed CO is mainly used to form alkyl intermediate substances, while non-dissociation adsorbed CO is mainly used for CO insertion into the above-mentioned alkyl substances to form higher alcohols [9]. Due to the existence of these processes, designing high-performance catalysts is extremely challenging. First, the catalyst must have at least two active sites acting as dissociation and non-dissociation adsorption of CO. Second, the ability of CO to dissociation and non-dissociation adsorb must reach a better balance in order to promote efficient conversion of syngas into higher alcohols. Third, how to improve efficiency while matching these two abilities. After decades of research, researchers have developed a variety of catalysts used for HAS. These catalysts can be mainly classified into four categories: modified methanol catalysts such as CuZn-based [10] catalysts; modified Fischer-Tropsch catalysts such as CuFe [11], CuCo [12], and CuNi-based [13] catalysts; noble metal catalysts such as Rh [14]; and Mo-based catalysts such as MoS2 [15], Mo2C [16], and MoOx [17]. Among them, modified methanol catalysts have poor carbon chain growth ability and high selectivity for methanol. Modified Fischer-Tropsch catalysts have wide product distribution and poor stability. Rh-based catalysts have excellent performance but low economic efficiency, making it difficult to achieve industrial application. Mo-based catalysts have adjustable valence state, sulfur resistance, and carbon deposition resistance, which are a highly promising class of catalyst for the synthesis of higher alcohols from syngas. Most of the review articles on the HAS that have been published so far are large-scale reviews covering almost all types of catalysts. However, the discussion on Mo-based catalysts is generally brief and not comprehensive or in-depth. Only Zaman et al. [18] has published a review on Mo-based catalysts since 11 years ago, and at that time the research on Mo-based catalysts was not in-depth and there were few literature sources. With the development of research on Mo-based catalysts applied in HAS, many excellent Mo-based catalyst literature have emerged in recent years. Therefore, it is necessary to make a more comprehensive review of Mo-based catalysts in HAS. This review aims to clarify the characteristics of various Mo-based catalysts by summarizing diverse preparation methods, the role of promoters (alkaline promoters, transition metal promoters) and support, different active phases of catalysts, and catalytic mechanisms to provide a reference for the design and preparation of high-performance Mo-based catalysts. This review is mainly divided into three parts: MoS2, Mo2C and other Mo-based (MoOx, Mo2N, MoP and MoSe2) catalysts, as shown in Fig. 1. Each part includes a summary of different promoters (alkaline promoters and transition metal promoters), active phases of catalysts, support, preparation methods and catalytic mechanisms. The focus of this review is on elucidating the multiple roles of promoters, clarifying the active phases of catalysts, the influence of supports and catalytic mechanisms. 2 Mo-based catalysts Research on the preparation of higher alcohols from syngas began in the 1930s and Mo-based catalysts are a typical type of catalyst for the preparation of higher alcohols from syngas. In the 1980s, Dow Chemical Company and Union Carbide Corporation discovered that Mo-containing Fe-based catalysts could catalyze CO hydrogenation to produce alcohols after impregnation with alkali metals [19]. Since then, Mo-based catalysts used for the synthesis of higher alcohols via syngas have received great attention and developed well. Currently, Mo-based catalysts mainly include MoS2, Mo2C, MoOx, MoP, Mo2N and MoSe2, which the first two have been studied earlier and have more literature sources. We will discuss them separately while discussing the latter four together. 2.1 MoS2-based catalysts MoS2-based catalysts are the most commonly used Mo-based catalysts for the synthesis of higher alcohols from syngas. MoS2-based catalysts have strong sulfur resistance due to their inherent sulfur content and also have high tolerance to carbon dioxide. This indicates that MoS2-based catalysts have strong adaptability to syngas and do not require strict control of the content of H2S and CO2 in the syngas. MoS2 catalysts also have strong anti-carbon deposition properties and can be used for syngas with low H2/CO, Table 1 lists the performance of MoS2-based catalysts in the HAS. 2.1.1 Effect of promoters on Mo2S-based catalysts Promoters are crucial for MoS2 catalysts in CO hydrogenation to produce higher alcohols, especially alkaline and transition metal promoters. The MoS2 catalysts without promoters displayed almost all short-chain hydrocarbons in CO hydrogenation. After the addition of alkali metal promoters, the MoS2-based catalysts inhibited the formation of hydrocarbons and significantly improved the selectivity of alcohols. Also, transition metal promoters can enhance the carbon chain growth ability of products. 2.1.1.1 Effect of alkali promoters on MoS2-based catalysts The introduction of alkali promoters into MoS2-based catalysts is extremely important for CO hydrogenation to the formation of higher alcohols. The effect of alkali promoters on the performance of MoS2-based catalysts is very complex. Alkali promoters could participate in the formation of the active phase of MoS2-based catalysts and also affect the dispersion, spatial structure and electronic properties of the MoS2 phase as well as regulating the acid-base sites of the catalyst. Potassium (K) is the most commonly used and currently the most effective alkali metal promoter. Alkali promoters have significant impact on the active phase of MoS2-based catalysts. Wang et al. [20] synthesized three K-Mo3Sx catalysts using an in-situ decomposition method and exhibited the different catalytic performance, which was caused by the formation of a new active phase K-Mo-S. Zeng et al. [21] designed a multi-layer K-MoS2 catalyst with well-contacted dual-site MoS2 and KMoS2 phases. The effect of alkali promoters on the electronic properties of MoS2-based catalysts. Permyakov et al. [22] used function density theory (DFT) to study the electronic properties of K on catalysts, indicating that K modification was found to hinder the σ-bonding of adsorbed molecules and stabilize hydride adsorption. After the adding of K, the promoted active site model on the M-edge slightly promotes the formation of hydride species and reduces CO adsorption energy on double vacancies. Therefore, K can act as a promoter for most active site models, but KFeMoS is an exception where K acts as a strong poison. Dorokhov et al. [23] demonstrated the effect of K on CoMoS phase active sites through DFT calculations. The transfer of electron density from K atoms to transition metal atoms (mainly to Co) and the reduction of electron deficiency in Co atoms leads to a decrease of Lewis acidity and CO and H2 adsorption energies in catalyst. Santos et al. [9] studied the of K-MoS2 catalysts by using a combination of in-situ infrared spectroscopy and kinetic studies. The presence of K not only changed the electronic properties of the catalyst but also stabilized alkoxide species, facilitating the formation of higher alcohols through increasing the probability of CO insertion and to some extent through base-catalyzed aldol condensation. Alkali promoters can enhance the dispersion of Mo metal on the support. Surisetty et al. [24] has reported that the K and Mo precursors were co-impregnated onto multi-walled carbon nanotubes using an equal volume impregnation method. By increasing the content of K from 3 wt% to 9 wt%, the interaction between K-Mo-O in the precursor was increased. In addition, the dispersion percentage of metallic Mo was increased from 20.2 % to 30.9 %. Most metal particles (80 %) were evenly distributed inside the tubes, with the remainder distributed on the outer surface of MWCNT. Dorokhov et al. [23] found that the presence of K is beneficial for increasing the stacking number and slab length of MoS2. An increase in potassium content to 15 wt.% leads to lateral adhesion of MoS2 slabs, resulting in MoS2 crystals with long edges and a corresponding decrease in corner site ratio, thereby improving alcohol selectivity. In general, the type, amount and method of introducing alkali promoters have an impact on MoS2-based catalysts. Toyoda et al. [25] found that the alcohol selectivity and chain growth probability of catalysts using K2CO3 were higher than those using nitrates. Morrill et al. [26] pointed out that when the K content in the catalyst is low, there will be more residual acidic sites on the catalyst, leading to dehydration and hydrogenation of ethanol and acquired an optimal K/Mo molar ratio of 1. Toyoda et al. [25] considered that the selectivity of higher alcohols was increased with the increase of K/Mo molar ratio. When the K/Mo molar ratio reached 0.6 from 0, the highest selectivity of higher alcohols was achieved. Li et al. [27] synthesized a Co-MoS2 catalyst with a K2CO3 promoter with an optimal K/Mo molar ratio of 0.5. The K/Mo molar ratio has a significant impact on MoS2-based catalysts, and different MoS2-based catalysts may have different optimal K/Mo molar ratios. When the K/Mo molar ratio is low, the promotion effect is not good and alcohol selectivity is low. As the K/Mo molar ratio is high, the K promoter can block or cover active sites on the surface of the catalyst, resulting in a decline of catalytic performance. Santos et al. [9] found that the alkali-promoting effect largely depends on the way the alkali is added. The distribution of K on fresh K-MoS2 catalysts is uneven and K redispersion occurs when exposed to reaction conditions. Two methods of adding K were used by Ferrari et al. [28] to promote the synthesis of higher alcohols from syngas using MoS2 catalyst: physical mixing and equal volume impregnation. Compared with K2CO3 and MoS2 catalysts prepared by physical mixing, that of catalysts prepared by equal volume impregnation showed poorer performance. From thermogravimetric analysis of the physical mixing method, it showed that sulfur was lost at temperatures above 330 °C, and showed randomly oriented small MoS2 microcrystals from transmission electron microscopy images, while longer MoS2 microcrystals were obtained by equal volume impregnation. Although the introduction method of K promoters has a great impact on the performance of MoS2 catalysts, there is no consensus on which method is best. 2.1.1.2 Effect of transition metal promoters on MoS2-based catalysts Typically, MoS2 catalysts promoted only by alkali metals produce a significant amount of methanol as the CO hydrogenation product. It is necessary to introduce transition metal promoters to improve the carbon chain growth ability and thus increase the formation of higher alcohols. Common transition metal promoters are Fischer-Tropsch elements, usually Fe, Co and Ni elements. There are also MoS2-based catalysts modified with other transition metal elements. The literature describes the use of transition metals in the construction of active phases in MoS2-based catalysts. Surisetty et al. [29] have reported that the K-MoS2 catalysts modified with transition metals Ni, Co, and Rh were prepared and applied in HAS. It was found that those transition metals reduced the reduction temperature of Mo+6. And, the MoS2 was the active phase in Rh-promoted catalysts, while Ni-Mo-S and Co-Mo-S phases are formed in Ni- and Co-promoted catalysts, respectively. In addition, the Ni-Mo-K/Al2O3 catalyst display higher hydrocarbons selectivity, but the above catalyst modified by Co can increase the alcohol activity and suppress hydrocarbon formation. The activity of Rh-promoted catalysts for higher alcohol synthesis is much higher than that obtained on rhodium-free catalysts. Yong et al. [30] synthesized a catalyst in which Ni participated in forming NiSx and NiMoSx phases. The high dispersion of NiSx and NiKMoSx and a large increase in the number of dual active sites in contact significantly enhanced the synergy between Ni and Mo, thereby enhancing CO hydrogenation activity and selectivity for higher alcohols. Li et al. [27] reported on a catalyst involving Co in constructing an active phase where fresh catalyst had highly dispersed Co-Mo-S active phase without detecting any Co9S8 phase. This was attributed to using pure H2 to activate the catalyst effectively suppressing formation of Co9S8 phase resulting in higher selectivity for higher alcohols. Xi et al. [31] reported that introducing Co into K-MoSx catalyst led to an increase in CH4 content indicating stronger hydrogenation ability possibly due to high content of CoS2 leading to formation of CoMoO4 phase resulting lower selectivity for higher alcohols. Formation of Co9S8 adjacent to K-promoted MoSx phase is an effective active phase for higher alcohol synthesis where dissociative adsorption occurs mainly on CO. Permyakov et al. [22] reported on the bimetallic (Me)MoS2 (Me = Nb, Fe, Co, Ni) sulfide system. The CO adsorption energy increases in the order of Ni<Co<Fe on the M-edge (the edge where molybdenum is located). The calculation results were confirmed by syngas conversion experiments. The promotion of Fe, Co or Ni at the S-edge (the edge where sulfur is located) of the catalyst causes catalyst deactivation and inhibits hydrogenation reactions. On the FeMoS2 and CoMoS2 catalysts, syngas conversion mainly occurs at the M-edge promotion sites. On the M-edge, transition metal promotion activity decreases in the order of FeMoS > CoMoS > > NiMoS. Zhang et al. [32] reported a Zn-modified MgAl mixed oxide-supported KNiMoS-based catalyst. The introduction of Zn can reduce the concentration of strong acid sites on the catalyst and weaken metal-support interactions to regulate MoS2 slab reducibility, sulfidation degree, length/stacking degree and dispersion to expose more active sites. NiSx and K-Ni have high synergistic effects in carbon chain growth and non-dissociative CO insertion processes to achieve higher total alcohol selectivity (56.5 %) and higher alcohol selectivity (82.2 %). Qi et al. [33] reported a Mn- and Ni-co-modified K/MoS2 catalyst with synergistic effects between Mn and Ni to promote increased selectivity for higher alcohols. Yang et al. [34] reported a La-promoted Mo-Co-K catalyst with significantly improved performance upon introduction of La under identical reaction conditions. Li et al. [35] found strong interactions between La and Ni that inhibited Ni aggregation to enhance surface dispersion while also facilitating close interactions between Ni and MoS2 for improved formation of higher alcohols. 2.1.2 Active phase of MoS2 catalysts Identifying the active phase of a catalyst is key to the catalyst research and has great significance for studying catalytic mechanisms and guiding the synthesis of catalysts. In recent years, people have used various methods to prepare MoS2-based catalysts with different active phases for the production of higher alcohols through CO hydrogenation. Surisetty et al. [29] reported that when Rh was used as a promoter, the observed active sites of Mo-MoS2. When Ni and Co were used as promoters, the active phase was Ni-Mo-S and Co-Mo-S phases, respectively. At the same time, diffraction peaks representing characteristic K-Mo-S phases in X-ray diffraction patterns of Mo-K/MWCNT catalysts promoted by cobalt sulfide were observed [36]. According to the edge model, the hydrogenation reaction mainly occurs at the edge of MoS2. The increase in particle size can enhance the active sites at the edge of MoS2 plates. The increase in stacking number of MoS2 crystals and partial increase in K active sites at edges lead to formation of alcohols and suppression of alkane [23]. Li et al. [27] reported a nanoplate-structured K-Co-MoS2 catalyst with highly dispersed Co-Mo-S active phase and no Co9S8 phase detected in fresh catalysts. During catalytic reaction, the formation of SH species stabilized Co-Mo-S phase. Xi et al. [31] believed that the higher Co content could promote the formation of CoS2 and CoMoO4 phases, resulting in the poor selectivity for higher alcohols. When Co is moderate, a Co9S8 phase will form between two K-promoted MoSx phases loaded with it. The authors speculated that Co9S8 phase is responsible for producing CHx*, which can produce branched-chain alcohol when transferred to K-MoSx phase. Yong et al. believe that by adjusting the interaction between metal and support to balance the dispersion and stacking of MoS2 plates, the abundant Mo edges are provided for dispersed Ni species to construct more active sites. The significant increase of highly dispersed and contacted dual active sites of NiSx and NiNKMoSx will endow them with efficient synergistic effects and enhance catalytic performance [30]. Wang et al. [20] believe that the significantly higher selectivity for higher alcohols of K-Mo3Sx-Ni(Ac) than K-Mo3Sx and K-Mo3Sx-Ni(L) is due to the formation of a new active phase K-Mo-S in K-Mo3Sx-Ni(Ac), while Ni only plays a role in further improving catalytic performance. Zheng et al. [37] reported that single-atom Ni loaded on Mo6S8 (Ni-SA/Mo6S8) increased the stability of reaction intermediates, which was conducive to CC bond formation, and Ni atoms directly participated in ethanol synthesis reaction. Wang et al. [38] believe that the key to improving MoS2 catalytic performance is to generate a large number of unsaturated sites and form abundant Ni-Mo-S phases on unsaturated sites. They synthesized a catalyst with Ni and Mo interactions, producing an active phase NiMo3Sx, which improved catalytic performance. Hensley et al. [39] reported on the study of catalyst deactivation using K-CoMoSx catalysts with equipment operating times ranging from 118 to 3969 h. In the absence of H2S co-feed, the alcohol selectivity decreased after several hundred hours of operation while the hydrocarbon selectivity increased. Desulfurization not only led to surface oxidation of the catalyst, but also increased surface acidity and caused alcohol dehydration. Surface coking blocked active sites and reduced catalyst performance. When continuous sulfidation with H2S co-feed was used, it was possible to reverse surface non-coking oxidation of the catalyst and maintain constant catalyst selectivity for thousands of hours. 2.1.3 Effect of supports on MoS2-based catalysts The support plays an important role in the component of catalyst. It generally has an excellent pore structure that can enhance the dispersibility of active component, and improve the diffusion efficiency of raw materials and products. it can interact with the active component to enhance catalytic performance and inhibit its agglomeration. In addition, it can also provide a moderate acidic or alkaline environment for the catalyst, which is benefit to the formation of target product. In terms of the support applied in MoS2-based catalyst, it generally divided into oxide supports and carbon material support. Common oxide supports have relatively strong acidic sites, and there is strong interaction between the support and active component, which may be not suitable for direct use as a support for synthesizing higher alcohols from syngas. Carbon support generally have a large surface area, porosity, good tolerance to acidic or alkaline environments, fewer acidic sites, less interaction with active phases, and good electronic conductivity, these advantages are beneficial for the synthesis of alcohols. Oxide supports are one of the most commonly used supports in MoS2-based catalysts. Toyoda et al. [25] prepared several molybdenum-based catalysts supported on Al2O3 by impregnation method. They found that when Al2O3 was prepared by using high-temperature calcination from 600 to 1000 °C, the selectivity of hydrocarbons decreased from 46 % to 21 %, but the CO conversion also decreased. This was attributed to a decrease in acid amount and acidic sites on Al2O3 with increasing calcination temperature. The strong acidic sites may be beneficial for hydrocarbon generation. Yong et al. [30] used MgAl bimetallic oxide as a support to achieve the best effect between the dispersion and stacking of MoS2 flakes by adjusting the interaction between metal and support. This provided rich Mo edges for Ni species and produced more active phase NiNKMoSx. Zhang et al. [32] used Zn-modified MgAl oxide as a support. The introduction of Zn reduced the concentration of strong acid sites on the catalyst and weakened the metal-support interaction, thereby regulating the reducibility, sulfidation degree, length/stacking degree and dispersion degree of MoS2 flakes. This exposed more active sites and improved the selectivity of higher alcohols. Ren et al. [40] synthesized an ordered mesoporous NiMg mixed metal oxide support that can restrict the growth of MoS2. The ordered mesopores restricted and regulated Mo-Ni interactions, significantly increasing the specific surface area and dispersion degree of MoS2 flakes with low stacking, appropriate size and dominant double-layer MoS2 stacking. Those improved CO conversion rate and selectivity for higher alcohols. Ren et al. [41] reported a KNiMoS/ZnCrAlS catalyst that showed obvious mesopores and macropores structure through Fig. 2 A and B with uniform periodic 3D ordered macropores with an average diameter of about 200 nm. These pores originated from hierarchical frameworks of KNiMo and ZnCrAl-O(E). Fig. 2C and D show that both support and catalyst have multi-level pore structures which increased their specific surface area while providing transport channels for reactants and products to improve CO conversion rate and selectivity for higher alcohols. Additionally, ZnCr has strong CO activation ability which is conducive to CO adsorption. Weaker metal-support interactions in layered structures can promote dominant double-layer stacked MoS2 flakes to expose more active sites. Additionally, Ren et al. [42] synthesized Mg-modified mesoporous SiO2 supports with tunable morphology and pore size using an improved Stöber method. The results indicated that the mesoporous Mg-modified SiO2 support achieved tunable MoS2 nanosheet structures through a confinement effect, thereby enhancing the dispersion of the NiMoS2 active phase. This enhancement led to improved selectivity and distribution of higher alcohols, with KNiMoS/Mg-MS-20 exhibiting the highest alcohol selectivity of 66.3 % and a C2+OH distribution of 80.5 %. Toyoda and colleagues[43] studied the effect of CeO2, SiO2 and Al2O3 as support on the catalytic performance of sulfide catalysts. In terms of CeO2 as support, the CO2 selectivity was significant decreased, and the higher alcohols selectivity was corresponding increased. This is attributed to CeO2’s ability to store large amounts of O* produced by dissociative adsorption of CO, converting it to Ce2O3 and then reducing it back to CeO2 with H*, thus avoiding the oxidation of CO* by O* to produce CO2. Carbons are used as excellent support for MoS2-based catalysts for catalyzing syngas production of higher alcohols. Wang et al. [44] reported an efficient Ni-Mo-K doped carbon nanotube sulfide catalyst. The authors believe that carbon nanotubes can adsorb and activate H2, creating a surface microenvironment with high concentrations of H adsorbates on the catalyst surface. This results in a sharp increase in the percentage of Mo4+/Mo5+ species on the catalyst surface relative to total Mo. In addition, active H species adsorbed on carbon nanotubes can easily be transferred to Ni-Mo-K active sites via hydrogen spillover assisted by carbon nanotubes. Osman et al. [19] studied CoMoS supported on powdered carbon materials (DAC and OBC-1) and carbon fiber materials (woven activated adsorption (TCA) and non-woven activated material (AHM)). The performance of powdered activated carbon catalysts confirmed a correlation between porosity and catalytic activity, with microporous Cat-DAC with smaller mesopores performing better than Cat-OBC-1 with higher mesopores. Cat-AHM has short and thin layers that increase the angle, substrate and side surfaces of the catalyst, forming active MoS2 microcrystals that improve catalytic performance. The lowest catalytic activity of Cat-TCA is due to long linear plate structures formed on the axial strip surfaces of commercial TCA activated carbon that limit exposure of active sites. Comparing the effect of metal oxide and carbon support on catalytic performance, the latter have significant advantages in the preparation of higher alcohols from syngas. Li et al. [45] prepared K-MoS2 catalysts using activated carbon and Al2O3 as support. Compared with Al2O3 support catalysts, the former have higher catalytic performance, which may be related to the interaction between the active phase and the support. Surisetty et al. [29] also compared the performance of Al2O3 and activated carbon support catalysts. Those selectivity and space-time yield were significantly higher than those of alumina support catalysts. Dorokhov et al. [23] found that compared to the pure Al2O3 support, the adding C to Al2O3 promoted ethanol synthesis and increased CO conversion rate. Osman et al. [46] synthesized K-Co-MoS2 catalysts using four supports: γ-Al2O3, carbon-coated γ-Al2O3 (CCA), activated carbon AG-3, and activated carbon BAW. Compared with pure γ-Al2O3 support catalysts, carbon-coated γ-Al2O3 support catalysts showed higher selectivity for alcohol, but activated carbon-loaded catalysts showed optimal catalytic performance, especially at higher temperatures where the CO conversion rate of activated carbon-loaded catalysts was higher than that of γ-Al2O3-based catalysts. The catalytic activity increased in the order of Al2O3 < CCA < AG-3 < BAW; it was inversely proportional to the logarithm of the number of acid sites on the catalyst; an increase in acidity would lead to a decrease in alcohol selectivity. Activated carbon support catalyst provided highest ethanol yield at highest CO conversion rate; this seems due to increased accumulation of KCoMoS2 as well as presence of micropores and a small amount of mesopores in the support. Claure et al. [47] reported a K-MoS2 catalyst supported on a mixed support of mesoporous activated carbon (C) and MgAl oxide, referred to as MMOC. The catalyst showed high selectivity for higher alcohols when using MMOC as the support. This is mainly due to the strong Mo-MMO interaction in the double layer of MoK/MMO and MoK/MMOC, which restricts the growth of MoS2 stacking layers. The authors found that during the reaction process, Mo species migrate from mesoporous carbon supports to MgAl oxide support, indicating that the interaction between C support and MoS2 is weak while that between MgAl oxide and MoS2 is strong. 2.1.4 Preparation methods of MoS2 catalysts The classical methods for preparing MoS2 include co-precipitation, thermal decomposition and hydrothermal methods. However, these methods usually result in severe stacking of synthesized MoS2 with low catalytic performance. In recent years, various methods have been developed to adjust the morphology, size and specific surface area of MoS2-based catalysts. Based on the edge model of molybdenum sulfide, researchers hope to obtain a smaller number of stacked layers and more edge defects in MoS2-based catalysts by improving synthesis methods so as to expose more active sites and improve catalytic performance. Qin et al. [48] synthesized KCoMoS2 catalysts with different structures using hydrothermal, co-precipitation and reverse microemulsion method, which the particle diameters and the specific surface areas of the catalysts were 33.39 nm&11.00 m2/g, 18.24 nm & 32.7 m2/g and 14.7 nm & 37.26 m2/g, respectively. The catalyst synthesized by reverse microemulsion method had the smallest size, the largest specific surface area. and fewer layers with smaller lateral dimensions than those prepared by other two methods which contained more stacked MoS2 layers. This method had the best selectivity for higher alcohols due to its shorter and thinner MoS2 layer structure which exposed more active sites. Konarova et al. [49] studied NiMoS2 catalysts prepared by microemulsion and hydrothermal methods, which was applied in the synthesis of alcohols; As shown in TEM images, it showed that highly ordered molybdenum sulfide plates containing up to seven layers were produced in the catalyst prepared by hydrothermal method with a specific surface area of 250 m2/g and an alcohol selectivity of only 15 %. In contrast, disordered sulfide layers were found in the catalyst prepared by microemulsion method with a high specific surface area of up to 300 m2/g, which exposed more active sites resulting in an alcohol selectivity of up to 61 %. However, characterization of used catalyst surfaces using X-ray photoelectron spectroscopy and inductively coupled plasma mass spectrometry elemental analysis detected significant sulfur loss in the microemulsion catalyst while only minor sulfur loss was observed in the hydrothermal catalyst. Paris et al. [50] synthesized K-Ni-MoS2 catalysts using a co-precipitation method in aqueous solution or microemulsion. The new microemulsion co-precipitation catalyst has higher catalytic performance than the traditional aqueous solution co-precipitation catalyst, which is mainly attributed to the enrichment of the promoter on the surface of the catalyst by the microemulsion method, which increases the concentration of the promoter on the surface of the catalyst. At the same time, the crystallinity of the surface of the catalyst prepared by microemulsion method is lower and more conducive to generating more active sites. Li et al. [51] prepared highly uniformly dispersed Ni/K/MoS2 catalysts under non-aqueous conditions using an ultrasound-assisted method. Compared with catalysts prepared by co-precipitation methods, ultrasound-assisted prepared catalysts showed better alcohol yield and lower olefin selectivity due to separated NiSx crystal particles formation related to hydrocarbon formation. Zeng et al. [21] used a wet chemical method to prepare K-MoS2 catalysts by mixing ammonium molybdate and sodium sulfide solutions and adding hydroxylamine hydrochloride under reflux conditions to obtain amorphous MoS2. This method can obtain multi-layered K-MoS2 catalysts with good contact between MoS2-KMoS2 dual sites. It is worth noting that higher alcohol formation deviates from Anderson-Schulz-Flory distribution in catalytic results. 2.1.5 Catalytic mechanisms of MoS2-based catalysts Santos et al. [9] used a combination of in situ infrared spectroscopy and kinetic studies to elucidate the mechanism of CO conversion on K-MoS2 catalysts. On the unpromoted MoS2 surface, non-dissociative adsorption of CO favors the H-assisted adsorption pathway via formyl species CHO, which easily leads to the formation of C and CHx species on sulfide surfaces. The K-promoted catalyst activate CO and partially hydrogenate it into hydrogenated intermediates, i.e., more easily generating RO-K The proximity of K to adsorbed methyl will favor CO insertion and stabilize acyl intermediates, further hydrogenating into C2H5O-K and finally into ethanol. At the same time, the authors conducted co-feed kinetic experiments with syngas and ethanol. In the case of unpromoted MoS2 catalysts, only hydrocarbons such as ethane were produced in the product stream. In the case of K-MoS2 catalysts, adding ethanol to syngas feed promoted the production of higher alcohols, mainly 1-propanol and 1-butanol. The authors stated that higher alcohol formation can occur not only through CO insertion but also through aldol condensation of short-chain alcohols. Dorokhov et al. [23] synthesized a KCoMoS/C/Al2O3 catalyst for the preparation of higher alcohols by CO hydrogenation. Based on experimental data and DFT calculation results, as shown in Fig. 3 , the authors proposed a catalytic reaction mechanism. CO is more easily adsorbed on active sites than H2, which means that after CO adsorption, the next step is to insert CO into the metal-hydrogen bond and then reduce it to form an adsorbed aldehyde. The adsorbed aldehyde is hydrogenated to form an alcohol without breaking the CO bond or forming a CC bond. If the hydrogenation reaction was not occurred, the CO bond was broken. Alkyl intermediates may participate in the formation of hydrocarbons or chain growth. The hydrolysis of CO intermediates proceeds through a transition state affected by steric hindrance and nucleophilic hydrolysis induced by high polarity of CO bonds. Methane and ethane dominate in syngas conversion products. K suppresses nucleophilic hydrolysis of CO bonds by reducing Lewis acidity, i.e., stabilizing alkoxide intermediates; selectivity for alcohol formation is determined by hydrolysis of CO bonds in aldehyde intermediates. Xi et al. [31] prepared K-Co-MoSx catalysts with different Co contents. The authors proposed that the formation of the C9S8 and MoSx phase adjacent to the K promoter enhanced the catalytic performance of K-MoSx. As shown in Fig. 4 , the Co9S8 phase mainly was used as the active phase of hydrocarbons formation. There are a large number of adsorbed CnHx* on the surface of C9S8. The authors hypothesized that such substances were effectively transferred from the Co9S8 phase to CH3CH2CH2O* adsorbed on K-MoSx to produce branched alcohols, completing the addition mechanism of CnHx*. In addition, the authors believed that straight-chain alcohols were formed by transferring CH3CH2CH2* adsorbed on Co9S8 to CO adsorbed on K-MoSx. Chen et al. [52] explored the catalytic mechanism of syngas to ethanol on a Cu4 cluster-modified MoS2(001) surface based on density functional theory. As shown in Fig. 5 , the authors believed that CO was hydrogenated on Cu4/MoS2 to form formyl (CHO). That was hydrolyzed to CH2, which is the most favorable CHx monomer. The formation of CC bonds was achieved by inserting CHO into CH2 to form C2 oxygen-containing compounds CH2CHO and then continuously hydrogenating to produce C2H5OH. Microstructural analysis showed that the Cu4 cluster provided non-dissociated CO and CHO species, while the interface between CH4 and MoS2 promoted the dissociation of CH2O to form CH2 monomers and promoted the formation of CC bonds in ethanol. Ren et al. [39] reported a multi-functional KNiMoS/ZnCrAlS catalyst with a multi-level pore structure and its catalytic mechanism for the synthesis of higher alcohols by CO hydrogenation. As shown in Fig. 6 , CO can be activated on both ZnCrAlS and KNiMoS. CO* adsorbed on ZnCrAlS mainly undergoes one-step hydrogenation to CHxO*, while KNiMoS can also generate CHxO*. CHxO* species can be further hydrogenated to produce methanol or transferred to KNiMoS for chain growth. CO* or CHxO* can be inserted into alkyl intermediates on KNiMoS to obtain chain-growth oxygen-containing intermediates. These oxygen-containing intermediates are further hydrogenated to produce higher alcohols. The dual-site synergy between ZnCrAlS and KNiMoS plays a key role in the generation of higher alcohols. The insertion of CO* or alkoxide species into alkyl species is the rate-determining step in the generation of higher alcohols. 2.2 Mo2C-based catalysts Mo2C is a catalyst that has been extensively studied in recent years due to its unique electronic structure. Similar to MoS2-based catalysts, the product of an unpromoted Mo2C catalyst is mainly hydrocarbons. Alkali promoters can significantly enhance the total alcohol selectivity of Mo2C-based catalysts. Transition metal promoters can enhance the carbon chain growth ability of Mo2C-based catalysts and thus enhance the selectivity for higher alcohols, Table 3 lists the performance of Mo2C-based catalysts in the HAS. 2.2.1 Effect of promoters on Mo2C-based catalysts 2.2.1.1 Effect of alkali promoters on Mo2C-based catalysts Lee et al. [55] used different potassium salts as promoters for Mo2C catalysts. As shown in Table 2 , K2SO4 and KCl only caused a slight increase in olefin selectivity and negligible alcohol yield. When K2CO3, KOH and CH3COOK were added to Mo2C, they promoted high selectivity for alcohols and light olefins. They believed that alkali promoters had an electronic effect by changing the surface electron density to promote the generation of alcohols and a geometric effect by blocking surface sites for reactant adsorption to reduce the conversion rate of CO. Chai et al. [56] and Xiang et al. [57] also agreed with this view that K reduced the hydrogenation activity of β-Mo2C, inhibited the direct hydrogenation of C1 intermediates to CH4 and CH3OH, thereby promoting the selective enhancement of higher alcohols. Xiang et al. also stated that K promoter enhanced the chain growth ability of β-Mo2C. Farkas et al. [58] studied the adsorption of methanol and ethanol on Mo2C surfaces and observed very stable CH3O-K and C2H5O-K species on K-promoted Mo2C surfaces. The stability of these oxygen-containing intermediates may be part of the reason why alkali-promoted carbides have increased alcohol selectivity. The K/Mo molar ratio is very important for Mo2C-based catalysts. An appropriate K/Mo ratio can have a good promoting effect, while an excessively high K/Mo ratio can cause blockage of active sites and reduce the catalytic activity. Chai et al. [56] reported that the optimal K/Mo molar ratio for K2CO3-promoted Mo2C-based catalysts is 0.1. Xiang et al. [57] studied K-promoted Mo2C catalysts and obtained the maximum alcohol yield when the K/Mo molar ratio was 0.2. Chiang et al. [59] studied K- and V-modified β-Mo2C catalysts and found that when the K/Mo molar ratio was 1.28, the K had the optimal promoting effect. Wu et al. [60] reported that when the K/Mo molar ratio was 0.21, an activated carbon-supported catalyst showed optimal selectivity. Kiai et al. [61]. introduced K into Co-Mo by impregnation method with an optimal K/Mo ratio of 0.6; increasing alkali metal loading improved dispersion of active metal Mo. Wang et al. [62]. used KOH as a precursor to promote Rh-Mo2C catalysts with an optimal K/Mo molar ratio of 0.2; they believed that it promoted Rh-Mo2C interface sites effectively improving catalytic performance while also promoting dispersion of transition metal Rh to inhibit further hydrogenation of olefins. Researchers have also reported other types of alkali promoters. Shou et al. studied Rb2CO3-promoted Mo2C/MgO catalysts [63] and Mo2C/α-Al2O3 catalysts [64]. Unpromoted Mo2C is an effective Fischer-Tropsch synthesis catalyst that produces only trace amounts of alcohols. When Rb2CO3 was used as a promoter, the alcohol selectivity of 5 wt.%Mo2C/MgO reached 61 %, and XANES characterization revealed structural changes in the Rb2CO3 promoter during the reaction. Compared to pure Mo2C, Rb-Mo2C greatly reduced the sensitivity of the catalyst to 1 % O2 passivation. Christensen et al. [65] investigated the promotion effect of Li, K and Cs on Mo2C catalysts. Cs2CO3 and K2CO3 were similar in their promotion properties, but K-promoted catalysts had higher activity and selectivity under the same conditions, while Li-promoted catalysts were more prone to produce hydrocarbons. The optimal M/Mo molar ratio was 0.164. Liu et al. [66] reported K, Mg and Ca-modified nanowire Mo2C. The K2CO3, Mg(OH)2·4MgCO3·6H2O and CaCO3 with Mo2C separately using an M/Mo molar ratio of 0.2 were physically mixed to the new catalyst. The order of promotion effect was: K>Mg>Ca. However, the CO conversion was decreased by adding K and Mg to the catalyst. In addition, promoters showed different effects on the ability of carbon chain growth. Potassium mainly enhanced carbon chain growth ability for alcohol products with higher selectivity but had little effect on alkanes. In terms of magnesium and calcium, they mainly improved alkane chain growth ability while inhibiting CH4 formation but increasing C2 H selectivity. 2.2.1.2 Effect of transition metal promoters on Mo2C-based catalysts Transition metal promoters can participate in the construction of the active phase of Mo2C-based catalysts. Xiang et al. [67] reported that Co participated in the generation of the active phase, forming new phases Co3Mo3C and Co2C in the Co-promoted K/β-Mo2C catalyst. The Co species has a strong promoting effect on ability of carbon chain growth, especially enhancing the promotion of methanol to ethanol. The synergy influence between Co and Mo is strong and depends on the Co/Mo molar ratio; when the Co/Mo molar ratio is 1/8–1/6, the promoting effect of Co on the synthesis of higher alcohol is best. Kiai et al. [61] found that K-Mo-C and Co3Mo3C sites involving Co participation exist on the surface of the catalyst. And the authors believe that the latter is also benefit for the alcohol synthesis. In addition, when the Co/Mo molar ratio was 0.6, the alcohol selectivity of the catalyst was highest. It was found that cobalt as promoter was identified as an adsorption site for active species in the molybdenum-cobalt carbide catalyst. Moreover, Arun et al. [68] proposed increasing oxygenate yield does not depend on formation of specific mixed metal/carbide phases but rather due to presence of closely contacted sites between Mo and Co reaction on surface of catalyst. Only when Mo and cobalt carbides are in close contact will it improve performance of catalyst. In addition to Co as the promoter in Mo-based catalysts, Zhao et al. [69] reviewed that the catalytic activity of Ni-promoted Mo2C catalyst was significantly higher than that of unpromoted Mo2C, and Ni content had a significant impact on product distribution. Besides, alcohol yield increased with increasing Ni content and reached a maximum when Ni/Mo molar ratio was 0.5. Xiang and colleagues[70] found that the K/β-Mo2C catalysts modified by F-T element (Ni, Co and Fe) displayed the key role in the product distribution. Ni and Co led to a decrease in the apparent activation energy of C1 C4 alcohols, while Fe led to a slight increase in the apparent activation energy of methanol and a decrease in the apparent activation energy of C2 C4 alcohols. The promoting effect of F-T elements followed the order: Ni > Co > Fe. Hao et al. [71] mentioned that Ni doping could promote the dispersion of Mo2C particles, and inhibit the formation of surface carbon on the catalyst, which increased its active surface area. Additionally, the interaction effect between Ni and Mo increased the electron cloud density of Mo species, promoting non-dissociative adsorption and insertion of CO. It is worth noting that as the Ni content increased, the number of carbon atoms on the surface lattice of the catalyst showed a volcano-type distribution. Aoki et al. [72] reported that in terms of pure Mo2C catalyst, the water-gas shift reaction was more intense, producing large amounts of CO2 while only small amounts were produced on CoMo carbide catalysts. The authors believe that the introducing Co into Mo2C can suppress water-gas shift reaction. A K/β-Mo2C catalyst promoted by iron carbide by Wang et al. [73]., was demonstrated that the introduction of Fe improved the selectivity of higher alcohols and iron carbide mainly promoted chain growth from methanol to ethanol. When the Fe/Mo molar ratio was 1/6, the catalyst achieved optimal alcohol selectivity. Xiang et al. [74]. studied an Fe-promoted β-Mo2C catalyst and found through XPS analysis of the surface elemental composition of the catalyst that both Fe and Mo were enriched on the surface of the catalyst, with surface contents far higher than theoretical contents. the addition of Fe increased the production of alcohols, especially the C2+OH (alcohols with 2 or more carbon atoms). Meanwhile, considerable amounts of C5+ hydrocarbons were formed, whereas methane selectivity greatly decreased. Chiang et al. [59]. reported that in terms of vanadium-modified Mo2C and K-Mo2C catalysts, the catalytic performance of the catalyst was optimal when the V/Mo weight ratio was 0.049. Co-modification of β-Mo2C with V and K showed a synergistic effect between them, especially improving the ethanol selectivity. It is worth noting that in the V-K-Mo2C system, adding H2O to trigger water gas shift reaction can improve C3 and C4 alcohol selectivity while maintaining high ethanol selectivity. Wang et al. [62] reported that from Rh-promoted K-Mo2C catalyst, where Rhδ+ species increased concentration of undissociated CO* intermediates on surface and significantly enhanced coupling ability between CO and alkyl species to form alcohol. 2.2.2 Active phase of Mo2C-based catalysts The active phase is important element of catalyst research. A clear understanding of the active phase helps in the study of catalyst mechanisms and the design of high-performance catalysts. Xiang et al. [67]. proposed that the new phases “Co3Mo2C and Co2C” were formed with the participation of Co promoter in the synthesized a K/Co/β-Mo2C catalyst. There is a strong synergistic effect between Co and Mo, which is key to improving catalytic performance. Kiai et al. [61] thought that K-Mo-C sites and Co3Mo3C phases exist in KCoMo2C catalysis, thereby increasing the selectivity for higher alcohols. Li et al. [75] found that the balance between Co0 and Co6Mo6C was crucial for catalyst performance, where CO dissociative adsorption and carbon chain elongation mainly occurred on Co0 sites, while non-dissociative adsorption of CO and CO insertion mainly occurred on Co6Mo6C phase. Zhao et al. [69] reported a Ni-Mo bimetallic carbide catalyst characterized by XRD to contain Ni metal, β-Mo2C and Ni6Mo6C phases; XPS characterization showed that when the Ni/Mo molar ratio was 0.5, it had the strongest synergistic effect; Ni6Mo6C may be the synthesis site for alcohol. Wang et al. [76] claimed that when Fe promoter was added, in the Mo2C-based catalyst product chain growth ability was enhanced due to “Fe3Mo3C and Fe3C” phases generated by Fe promoting K/β-Mo2C catalyst. Asundi and colleagues[68] reported that by the in situ X-ray absorption spectroscopy, the prepared catalyst is composed of carbide and bimetallic components. And it is found that the active phases are MoC1-x and Co2C. Through in situ infrared characterization, the Mo and Co atoms on the surface of the catalyst were determined to be the adsorption sites for active substances. Liakakoua et al. [77] put forword an effective method to demonstrate the formation of NiMo carbides. The authors hypothesized that NiMo carbides are active centers for non-dissociative adsorption of CO, which combines with dissociative adsorption of CO on Mo2C sites to result in the formation of higher alcohols. A stability test over 400 h showed significant deactivation of the catalyst with a decrease in activity by about 48 %. The decrease in catalyst performance was due to separation of NiMo carbide phase, formation of hydrated nickel oxide and K2Mo2O7 phase. Wang et al. [73] suggested that iron carbide and K/β-Mo2C may have a synergistic effect, forming a “K-Fe-Mo-C” species favorable for alcohol synthesis. Xiang et al. [74] found through XPS analysis at working temperature that both Mo and Fe were enriched on the surface of the Fe-modified K/Mo2C catalysts. Intermediate valence states such as Mo4+ may be responsible for alcohol generation while low valence states such as Mo0 and Mo2+ may be responsible for high activity and selectivity towards hydrocarbons. 2.2.3 Effect of supports on Mo2C-based catalysts Supports are also important for the catalytic performance of Mo2C. Usually, there are two types of support: oxide supports and carbon supports. Shou et al. [63] reported on a Rb-Mo2C catalyst with MgO as the support. The study showed that Mo2C was highly dispersed on magnesium oxide with an average particle diameter of only 2–3 nm, and enhanced the dispersibility of Mo2C. X-ray absorption spectroscopy characterization found that passivated Mo2C/MgO was more easily oxidized than Mo2C and after 4 h under reaction conditions, the passivated part was partially reduced and there was an oxidized state of Mo during the catalytic reaction. Wu et al. [60] designed some effective supported K/Mo2C catalysts using activated carbon, carbon nanotubes and titanium dioxide as support. Compared to bulk Mo2C, supported Mo2C had significantly higher activity and selectivity for total alcohols. Among them, the conversion rate of CO reached a maximum value when 20 wt%Mo2C was loaded on activated carbon. As the loading amount of Mo2C on activated carbon increased, the selectivity for higher alcohols increased and reached a maximum value on bulk catalysts while the selectivity for methanol followed an opposite trend. The titanium dioxide support catalyst had better higher alcohols selectivity but its thermal stability limited its use as a support for Mo2C due to its high carburizing temperature (750 °C). The effect of carbon nanotube support was between activated carbon and titanium dioxide, but due to the high cost, the latter were less attractive than activated carbon. Chai et al. [56]. reported in situ synthesis of β-Mo2C nanoparticles using graphite mesoporous carbon (GMC), commercial activated carbon, and carbon black as supports. By comparing the catalytic performance of carbon-supported Mo2C with bulk Mo2C it was shown that CO conversion rate increased with decreasing size of Mo2C particles regardless of support. Compared to activated carbon and carbon black GMC showed a significant improvement in catalytic activity due to its ability to form smaller Mo2C particles Meng et al. [16] synthesized a porous nano-catalyst, Ni/K/Mo2C@LC, using a carbon support derived from bamboo lignin. The authors suggested that the open mesoporous lignin carbon provided larger metal particles, which enhanced the hydrogenation capability. This configuration better balanced the no-dissociative and dissociative adsorption sites for CO during the higher alcohol synthesis reaction, thereby improving the catalytic performance. Under optimal reaction conditions, the catalyst achieved a space-time yield as high as 0.455 g/gcat/h. 2.2.4 Preparation methods of Mo2C-based catalysts Molybdenum carbide catalysts are generally prepared using the classical temperature-programmed reduction method. Depending on the carbon source used, it can be divided into gas-phase carbon source carburization and solid-phase carbon source carburization. The gas-phase carbon source is a mixture of a carbon-containing gas and hydrogen, such as CH4/H2 and C2H2/H2. The solid-phase carbon source is generally a carbon-containing organic compound such as glucose or hexamethylenetetramine, and the commonly used molybdenum source is ammonium heptamolybdate. Marquart et al. [78] reported the effect of synthesis methods on the surface properties of molybdenum carbide. Generally speaking, the final carburizing temperature is between 630 and 1000 °C, with a heating rate of 1–10 °C/min and held at the final carburizing temperature for 2–5 h. When the final carburizing temperature exceeds 760 °C, graphitic deposited carbon may occur on the catalyst. After carburizing is completed and cooled to room temperature, it can be passivated with 1 % O2/N2 for 1–12 h to obtain β-Mo2C. From the results of In-situ XRD, it confirmed that MoO3 undergoes phase transition to β-Mo2C at 650 °C. If fresh β-Mo2C is not passivated, it will partially oxidize to MoO2 after exposure to air. However, even after passivation Raman spectra of MoO3 can still be observed after β-Mo2C is exposed to air. Passivated β-Mo2C and in-situ β-Mo2C have similar CO conversion rates but passivated β-Mo2C shows higher oxygenate and total organic product yields which are attributed to the influence of MoO3 on the catalyst surface. Zhao et al. [69] prepared NiMo bimetallic carbide catalysts using the sol-gel method. Ethylene glycol and citric acid were used to complex nickel nitrate and ammonium heptamolybdate, and then a dry gel was obtained. The gel was calcined at 973 K for 5 h under the Ar flow and gradually passivated under a 2.0 vol% O2/Ar atmosphere. After the decomposition of the organic gel, a loose porous structure can be constructed inside the catalyst, as shown in Fig. 7 . The catalyst prepared by the sol-gel method has a large specific surface area, small and uniform molybdenum carbide nanoparticles with a particle size of 3–4 nm, which is conducive to exposing more active sites and improving catalytic performance. Liu et al. [79] reported a one-pot hydrothermal co-hydrolysis-carbonization method using C6H12O6 and ammonium heptamolybdate as starting materials to prepare carbonaceous spheres embedded with highly dispersed Mo2C nanoparticles. The catalyst prepared by this method has a large specific surface area and rich mesoporous structure due to the influence of MoO3 and d-C6H12O6 molecules on the structure of the catalyst during hydrothermal treatment. The authors also investigated the effect of different carburizing atmospheres on the catalysts. Under an Ar atmosphere, carbonized samples seemed to only have surface carbonization, while samples carbonized under H2 atmosphere had uniform carbonization on both surface and interior. Li et al. [75] reported a CoMo bimetallic carbide with MOF-assisted strategy. As shown in Fig. 8 , this method is based on the confinement effect of ZIF-67 and in-situ carbonization, allowing Co and Mo to be in close contact. After pyrolysis under N2 atmosphere, metal particles are simultaneously embedded in N-doped C matrixes. This method enables close contact between Co and Mo, enhancing their synergistic effect between Co and Mo effectively improving selectivity for higher alcohols. At the same time thanks to confinement protection from N-doped C scaffold, the catalyst showed excellent stability; no deactivation was observed during 100 h long-term stability test. He et al. [80] employed a hard template method to prepare a series of Mo2C catalysts with a hierarchical porous structure. Compared to bulk catalysts, the CO conversion rate increased from 5.1 % to 17.6 %, while the distribution of higher alcohols improved from 60.4 % to 70.5 %. The authors attributed the enhanced catalytic performance to the increased number of active sites and the synergistic effects between the multivalent Mo species. 2.2.5 Catalytic mechanisms of Mo2C-based catalysts The reaction of Mo2C based catalysts catalyzing the conversion of CO to higher alcohols is also very complex, including some elementary reactions. But the important steps are still the dissociation and adsorption of CO to generate CHx, the generation of CC bonds, and the insertion of CO. Zhang et al. [81] used density functional theory to study the mechanism of synthesis gas conversion to C2+ oxygen-containing compounds on the Cu/β-Mo2C catalyst interface. The calculation results are shown in Fig. 9 A, B, and CO first dissociatively adsorbs at the catalyst interface on the Cu/β-Mo2C (001) surface to form C*, which is then hydrogenated to form CH* and then CHx species. Compared with the formation of CH3OH, Cu/β-Mo2C (001) showed better selectivity for CH formation. For the formation of C2 oxygen-containing compounds, CHO insertion into CH to form CHCHO is the optimal pathway. As shown in Fig. 9-D, electronic and structural property analysis (blue and yellow shaded areas represent charge loss and gain respectively) indicates that strong charge transfer occurs between Cu and Mo2C forming a synergistic effect with a rich charge area formed at the interface between Cu and Mo2C where CH formation and CHO insertion occur followed by the generation of CHCHO. Dang et al. [82] systematically studied the mechanism of synthesis gas conversion to C2 oxygen-containing compounds on the Mo2C (001) surface using density functional theory calculations. The Mo-Mo bridge site on the Mo2C surface is the active center for CO hydrogenation. Due to the high energy barrier of CO, direct dissociation of CO on the Mo2C (001) surface is difficult, while H-assisted CO dissociation easily occurs. The reaction pathway is shown in Fig. 10 . CO and H2 transition from gas phase to adsorbed state with H2 undergoing dissociative adsorption to produce H*. Non-dissociatively adsorbed CO* generates CHO* under the action of H*, some CHO* undergoes CO bond cleavage and deoxygenation to form CH3* species while other CHO* inserts into CH3* species forming CH3CHO species which eventually hydrogenates to form CH3CH2OH with K promoter enhancing the activity of CH3 and CHO coupling. CHO* species can also undergo deep hydrogenation to produce CH3OH. 2.3 Other Mo-based catalysts In recent years, as the Mo-based catalysts have been intensively studied, MoOx, MoP, Mo2N and MoSe2 catalysts have also accumulated some literature reports, Table 4 lists the performance of other Mo-based catalysts in the HAS. 2.3.1 Effect of promoters on other Mo-based catalysts 2.3.1.1 Effect of alkali promoters on other Mo-based catalysts Aslam et al. [85] reported the synthesis of CoMo bimetallic carbon spheres through glucose-mediated in situ hydrothermal reduction. The authors introduced K promoter in three ways: in situ hydrothermal growth, wet impregnation and alkali (KOH) surface reaction. The first two methods used KNO3 as the K precursor with a K/Mo molar ratio of 0.14 while the alkali surface reaction method used KOH as the K precursor. In situ doping of K by hydrothermal method did not reduce the surface area and pore volume of the catalyst while impregnation and alkali surface reaction methods significantly decreased the catalyst surface area and pore volume. The selectivity for higher alcohols increased from 16 % to 28 % using hydrothermal reduction method which was attributed to close contact between K and MoCo metal nanoparticles due to in situ doping of K and increased concentration of MoO2. Catalyst prepared by impregnation of K showed poor selectivity for higher alcohols. Results indicate that only when present in appropriate proportions and close to active metals can K enhance alcohol selectivity. Zaman et al. [86]. reported on the study of CO hydrogenation performance of MoP-SiO2 catalyst. On the un-promoted MoP catalyst, the selectivity of CH4 was as high as 40 %. The introduction of K significantly inhibited the selectivity of CH4. The selectivity of C2+ oxides increased with the increase of K/Mo molar ratio and reached a maximum value of 76.6 % when the K/Mo molar ratio was 3.2. In addition to ethanol-containing oxygen compounds, there were also acetaldehyde and acetone. Zaman et al. [87] analyzed that K-promoted MoP-SiO2 did not have enough hydrogenation ability to reduce acetaldehyde and acetone to ethanol and isopropanol. Xu et al. [88] believed that K could enhance the alkalinity of CoMoP catalysts, enhance the interaction between MoP and CoMoP, promote the rearrangement of electron density in Mo species, form a large number of Mo4+ species, leading to an increase in C2+ oxygen-containing compound selectivity. However, a higher alkali content would also reduce the surface area of the catalyst and block active sites. The authors believed that an appropriate K/Mo molar ratio was 1.0. Ten Have et al. [89] used KNO3 as a precursor for K and believed that K could promote the formation of MoP phases while acting as an alkaline site in catalysts and stabilizing formyl intermediates during catalysis. Valle et al. [90] through in-situ XRD analysis, believed that under working conditions, the presence of potassium pyrophosphate might be responsible for significant differences in performance between promoted and un-promoted samples but how potassium pyrophosphate specifically participates in reactions remains to be determined. Zaman et al. [91] also investigated the promotion of K on Mo2N catalysts. Unpromoted Mo2N has higher hydrocarbon selectivity, while K-promoted Mo2N enhances the selectivity of oxygen-containing compounds. The introduction of K leads to the formation of K-Mo+ species, thereby improving CO insertion. At higher K loadings, the formation of K2MoO4 reduces the distribution of K in Mo2N, thereby weakening CO insertion. Zaman [92] also compared the promotion of Li and Cs on Mo2N for CO hydrogenation. The introduction of Li into Mo2N mainly generated Li2MoO4 and δ-MoN phases. This catalyst showed higher selectivity for olefins and non-alcoholic liquid oxygen-containing compounds. On Cs-Mo-N, methanol and ethanol were mainly produced, which was attributed to Cs being more easily transferred electrons to Mo than Li, thereby stabilizing Moδ+ sites and promoting CO insertion into CxHy to produce alcohols. Qu et al. [93] reported a new type of MoSe2-based catalyst in which the K promoter promoted the formation of a K-Mo-Se active phase. When the K/Mo molar ratio was 1.0, the total alcohol selectivity on K-MoSe2 reached 58.7 %. With increasing amounts of K promoter, the contents of Mo4+ and Mo5+ gradually decreased while that of Mo6+ species gradually increased. The authors believe that the introduction of K is conducive to the formation of Mo6+ species which are active sites for dissociative adsorption of CO and can promote alcohol chain growth. However, this interpretation differs significantly from other explanations regarding different valence states in other Mo-based catalysts. 2.3.1.2 Effect of transition metal promoters on other Mo-based catalysts Wu et al. [94]. added a small amount of Co-modified multi-walled carbon nanotubes to the Co-Mo-K oxide-based catalyst, which promoted the increase in the concentration of catalytically active species Mo+4 and CoO/Co3O4 on the catalyst surface, thereby enhancing the selectivity of higher alcohols. Xu et al. [88] reported that the Co transformed the phosphide from MoP to CoMoP phase, improving the dispersion of active components and exposing more active sites. Zaman et al. [95] reported a Rh-promoted K-MoP/SiO2 catalyst. Rh enhanced the selectivity of the catalyst for hydrocarbons, especially methane, while only slightly increasing its selectivity for ethanol, indicating that oxygen-containing compounds were produced on the K-MoP surface. Xie and et al. [96] studied Mn-doped K-Co-Mo catalysts. Mn doping significantly enhanced the selectivity of higher alcohols in these catalysts. The distribution of alcohol products deviated from ASF law and methanol selectivity was significantly suppressed. This was mainly attributed to Mn enhancing interactions between Co and Mo promoting formation of a Co-Mo-O active phase. At same time introduction of Mn significantly reduced number strong acid sites promoting formation weak acid sites. Addition Mn enhanced adsorption linear bridge CO which facilitated carbon chain growth formation higher alcohols. These effects all contributed to enhanced selectivity higher alcohols in these catalysts. Zhang et al. [97] prepared MoO3/SiO2 catalysts promoted by transition metals (Ni, Co, Cu and Ru) using atomic layer deposition. The addition of transition metals to MoO3 increased the activity of the catalyst by an order of magnitude. H2-D2 exchange rate measurements showed that the introduction of transition metal promoters increased the efficiency of H2 dissociation and H could spill over from the transition metal to Mo species. Chemical adsorption measurements of CO showed that the transition metal promoted catalysts had similar numbers of strong and weak adsorption sites. The authors believe that strong adsorption sites come from transition metals and weak adsorption sites may come from molybdenum oxide. Have et al. [89] studied K-MoP/SiO2 catalysts promoted by transition metals Co, Ni and Pd. After introducing Co and Ni, the conversion rate of the catalyst decreased from 2 % to 0.2 % and 0.02 %, respectively. Co and Ni seemed to act as poisons rather than promoters, which is very different from other molybdenum-based catalysts studies. The Pd promoter increased the conversion rate of CO but produced alcohols with shorter C chain lengths. 2.3.2 Active phases of other Mo-based catalysts Bian et al. [98] prepared MoO3-based catalysts with Al2O3 as the support. As the Mo loading increased, the catalysts formed the same K-Mo-O species, but the dispersion of K-Mo species decreased. The authors believed that the dispersion state of Mo species and the content of reduced Mo species affected CO total conversion rate, and the acidity of catalysts controlled mixed alcohol selectivity. Aslam et al. [85] reported a bimetallic MoCo oxide carbon sphere produced by glucose-mediated in situ hydrothermal reduction. The authors believed that the active site of this catalyst was very close MoO2 and Co sites on spatial positions within carbon scaffold. Kang et al. [99] and Valle et al. [90] indicated that active phase of MoP-based catalysts was MoP phase. Zaman et al. [92] investigated Li and Cs-promoted Mo2N-based catalysts. Unpromoted catalyst showed mainly γ-Mo2N phase. While Li-promoted molybdenum nitride catalyst showed δ-MoN phase, a small amount of γ-Mo2N phase and Li2MoO4, authors attributed enhanced oxygenate selectivity of this catalyst to formation of Li2MoO4 phase. And Cs-promoted molybdenum nitride mainly produced γ-Mo2N phase, with increasing Cs loading δ-MoN phase would appear. Compared with Li-promoted molybdenum nitride, Cs-Mo2N had higher oxygenate selectivity. Qu et al. [93] reported a novel MoSe2-based catalyst, authors attributed high selectivity for ethanol to formation of K-Mo-Se active phase, as well as synergistic effect of multivalent states (Mo4+, Mo5+ and Mo6+) in active phase. 2.3.3 Effect of supports on other Mo-based catalysts Bian et al. [98] synthesized K-MoO3 catalysts using Al2O3 as a support. As the Mo loading increased, K-Mo-O species were formed, but the dispersion of these K-Mo species decreased. The acidity of the catalyst decreased significantly with increasing Mo loading, and the activity of ethanol dehydration changed in parallel with acidity. The dispersion state of Mo species and the content of unreduced Mo species affected the total conversion rate of CO, while the acidity of the catalyst controlled the selectivity to mixed alcohols. Zhang et al. [100] synthesized K-promoted catalysts derived from Ni-Mo silicates by ammonia steaming method. The layered structure of silicate provided strong metal-support interaction, improved Mo metal dispersion and showed adjustable surface acid-base properties. In addition, silicate nanotubes can provide confinement effect through nanoscale channels to improve catalyst stability. Ma et al. [101] developed a Ni-Mo-K catalyst doped with CNTs modified by metal Ni. Although CNTs were doped into the catalyst as a promoter, they can also explain some support-like problems. The surface of CNTs has sp2 hybridization of C. After Ni modification, it has good adsorption for H2 and can produce a high-concentration adsorbed H surface microenvironment on the surface of the catalyst. The high-concentration adsorbed H in this microenvironment can also inhibit the water-gas shift reaction. At the same time, it can also increase the proportion of two catalytically active species: NiO(OH) and Mo4+/Mo5+. Lv et al. [102] prepared an activated carbon-supported K-Co-Mo catalyst by sol-gel method. Compared with unsupported catalysts, activated carbon-supported K-Co-Mo has better selectivity for higher alcohols. This is mainly because activated carbon-supported catalysts have larger active surface area and porosity, which is conducive to dispersion of active sites and reduction of metal particle size. The hollow structure can increase the residence time of intermediate products on the catalyst. Liakakou et al. [103] also studied the effect of activated carbon support on catalyst performance. Activated carbon-supported catalysts led to a 3-fold increase in selectivity for higher alcohols, which may be due to reduced crystallinity of NiMoO4 phase and partial phase transformation. After pretreatment with HNO3 on activated carbon support, CO conversion rate increased significantly, which was related to reduction in ash content and high acidity after acid treatment of samples. The authors attributed the improvement in activity to better dispersion of active phases on activated carbon support and more complete exposure of active site Ni-O-Mo sites. Luk et al. [104] synthesized CoMo/CNF catalysts using carbon nanofibers (CNF) as the support. Compared with traditional oxide and amorphous carbon supports, carbon nanofibers have lower specific surface area but higher selectivity and stability for higher alcohols. This may be due to excellent electronic effects and improved metal dispersion by preparing catalysts using citric acid-sol method. Have et al. [89] synthesized MoP-based catalysts using amorphous silica, mesoporous silica and mesoporous carbon as supports. The results showed that the catalytic effect of amorphous silica was extremely poor, while mesoporous silica improved catalytic performance and stabilized nano-sized MoP particles with controllable size distribution and confinement effect. However, mesoporous carbon-supported catalysts had the best CO conversion rate and selectivity. Valle et al. [90] also studied the effect of mesoporous silica and mesoporous carbon supports on MoP catalysts. MoP catalysts on mesoporous carbon were more easily reduced and achieved better crystalline MoP phase at lower temperatures. There was strong MoP-support interaction on the mesoporous carbon support which promoted reduction of the catalyst and improved catalytic activity and selectivity for higher alcohols. It can be seen that mesoporous carbon support plays a good role in synthesizing higher alcohol catalysts from syngas. 2.3.4 Preparation methods of other Mo-based catalysts Tavasoli et al. [105] synthesized MoO3-K2O/CNTs catalysts using microemulsion technology. At higher metal loading levels, a very narrow metal particle size distribution was produced. The MoO3 particle size decreased from an average of 7.1 nm to 4.5 nm, exposing more active centers and significantly improving catalyst performance. Luk et al. [104] compared KCoMo catalysts prepared by dry impregnation, sol-gel method and ball milling method. Due to the complexation of citric acid, the sol-gel method with citric acid can improve metal dispersion, expose more active sites and increase the yield of higher alcohols. Aslam et al. [85] reported a bimetallic MoCo carbon sphere produced by glucose-mediated in situ hydrothermal reduction. In this method, glucose can derive a carbon scaffold with MoO2 and Co active sites very close inside the carbon scaffold which is conducive to CO hydrogenation synthesis of higher alcohols. Zhang et al. [100] synthesized NiMo silicate precursor by steaming ammonia method and then calcined at high temperature to synthesize K-(NiMo)Si-PS catalyst. The preparation of NiMo silicate precursor by this method provides a basis for metal-support interaction. The surface of the catalyst has suitable acidic and basic sites and the silicate nanotubes produced also have a confinement effect on metal particles. The selectivity for higher alcohols of the catalyst prepared by this method reached 43.8 % and stability test reached 200 h which was significantly better than deposition and wet impregnation methods. Li et al. [106] used radio frequency induction thermal plasma method, hydrothermal method and programmed temperature reduction method to synthesize MoO2 catalysts respectively. As shown in Fig. 11 , radio frequency induction thermal plasma synthesis produced a new type of core-shell structure catalyst (MoO2-Pla) with crystalline core MoO2 and chain mail-like amorphous MoOx shell. Compared with MoO2 catalysts synthesized by hydrothermal method and programmed temperature reduction method, the ultra-stable chain mail-like particles formed on the surface during ultra-high temperature and rapid quenching process had better selectivity for higher alcohols while having extremely strong stability still having high catalytic activity after testing for 300 h under laboratory conditions. Xu et al. [88] synthesized carbon-modified KCoMoP catalysts using sol-gel method. The catalysts prepared by this method had small metal particle size and uniform distribution and had higher selectivity for higher alcohols. Kang et al. [99] prepared MoP@C catalysts by precursor pyrolysis method and programmed temperature reduction method respectively. Precursor pyrolysis method was to prepare carbon-coated MoP by pyrolyzing phosphorus-containing dimolybdenum carbonyl clusters. The particle size of the catalyst prepared by programmed temperature reduction method was about 40 nm while the metal particle size of the precursor pyrolysis method was only 2–5 nm which greatly improved the dispersion of the catalyst and exposed more active sites. Carbon in precursor pyrolysis method can act as a structural promoter and the catalyst showed good anti-sintering performance. After catalytic testing for 180 h, its catalytic activity and selectivity remained basically unchanged. Qu et al. [93] reported a MoSe2 catalyst for selective conversion of syngas to ethanol. MoSe2 was prepared by reducing ammonium molybdate and selenium powder with sodium borohydride as reducing agent through hydrothermal method. The K-Mo-Se catalyst prepared by this method had high selectivity for ethanol which was attributed to the synergistic effect of multiple Mo species such as Mo+4, Mo+5 and Mo+6 in active phase and the authors believed that low-valent Mo+4, Mo+5 and high-valent Mo6+ were dual active sites promoting formation of higher alcohols. 2.4.5 Catalytic mechanisms of other Mo-based catalysts Muramatsu et al. [Anon., 107] prepared a series of MoO2/SiO2 catalysts. The authors believed that the formation of alcohols required two Mo species: metal Mo and MoO2. CO dissociated on Mo to form surface carbides which were then hydrogenated to form hydrocarbon intermediates while CO insertion occurred on MoO2 where CO was inserted into hydrocarbon intermediates and further hydrogenated to produce higher alcohols. Schaidle et al. [108] synthesized a series of Mo-based carbides and Mo-based nitrides catalysts. The authors found that the TOF of Mo2C catalyst was an order of magnitude higher than that of Mo2N catalyst which was attributed to the fact that the activation energy barrier for CO dissociation on Mo2C was significantly lower than that for activating CO on Mo2N. The authors also stated that both Mo2C and Mo2N could directly dissociate CO but only the Mo2N catalyst seemed to follow the carbide mechanism. On the surface of Mo2C without pre-adsorbed H2, CC coupling on the surface of Mo2C promoted by molecularly adsorbed CO indicated that the main pathway for higher hydrocarbons was through oxygenate mechanism. Zaman et al. [91] synthesized Mo2N and K-Mo2N catalysts and studied their performance in CO hydrogenation. As shown in Fig. 12 , the authors believed that hydrocarbon intermediates were mainly formed on non-K-promoted active sites such as Mo3+ and K-promoted active sites such as Mo3+ could undergo non-dissociative adsorption of CO where non-dissociatively adsorbed CO could be continuously hydrogenated to produce methanol while at this active site, molecularly adsorbed CO could be inserted into CHx* where obtained intermediate was further hydrogenated to produce oxygenates. 3 Conclusion and future perspectives The HAS can address the energy crisis and greenhouse effect, offering significant economic and environmental benefits. There are mainly four types of catalysts for this process, with Mo-based catalysts receiving considerable attention due to their adjustable valence states, sulfur tolerance, and resistance to carbon deposition. However, developing Mo-based catalysts with high activity, selectivity, and stability remains a significant challenge. This small review summarizes literature on various types of molybdenum-based catalysts for preparing higher alcohols from syngas with the aim of providing assistance in designing and preparing Mo-based catalysts. We divide Mo-based catalysts into MoS2, Mo2C and other Mo-based catalysts (MoOx, MoP, Mo2N and MoSe2) summarize the effects of various types of promoters (alkaline promoters and transition metal promoters) active phases support effects preparation method effects catalytic mechanisms. (1) Promoters are crucial for Mo-based catalysts to catalyze the preparation of higher alcohols from syngas and seem to play similar roles for different Mo-based catalysts. Alkali promoters have multiple effects on catalysts such as promoting dispersion of Mo affecting electron density of Mo metal thereby enhancing CO insertion ability stabilizing oxygen-containing intermediates etc. thereby improving selectivity for alcohols. Transition metal promoters mainly enhance the dissociative adsorption ability of CO increase the concentration of hydrocarbon species on the surface of the catalyst thereby improving the carbon chain extension ability of the product. Many authors have stated that transition metals and Mo metals need to be spatially close enough to have good promotion effect.
