(2) Active phase is key to catalyst design and different types of Mo-based catalysts have different active phases due to different valence states of Mo metal. The active phase of MoS2-based catalysts is mainly (K)-transition metal-Mo-S phase where transition metals may exist in the form of transition metal sulfides or NiMo3Sx active phase forming solid solution structure. In addition to (K)-transition metal-Mo-C phase molybdenum carbide-based catalysts also have various solid solution active phases such as Co3Mo3C, Co6Mo6C, Fe3Mo3C and Ni6Mo6C etc. The active phase of MoOx-based catalysts has K-Mo-O species and also has very close spatial positions between MoO2 and Co sites while the active phase of MoP-based catalyst is just MoP and K-Mo-Se phase is formed in MoSe2 catalyst. (3) Support plays a very important role in preparing higher alcohols from syngas. Acidic sites can increase CO conversion rate but also promote dehydration of alcohols thereby reducing selectivity for alcohols while basic sites have opposite effects so balancing acidity and basicity of catalysts to increase yield of higher alcohols is an important issue. Larger specific surface area can expose more active sites while suitable pore structure can improve entry of feed gas and removal of products but single pore structure may not meet requirements so multi-level pore structure may be a better choice. In addition, interaction strength between support and active metals also needs to be considered as metal-support interaction can affect surface coordination of metals thereby affecting activity selectivity and stability of catalysts. It is worth noting that compared with oxide supports carbon supports have unique advantages in preparing higher alcohols from syngas. (4) The preparation method of catalysts is the focus of catalyst research. Suitable preparation methods form a good catalytically active phase, smaller metal particles with more exposed active sites and suitable pore structure. Compared to traditional methods such as thermal decomposition and hydrothermal methods, microemulsion method, sol-gel method, radio frequency induction plasma method and atomic layer deposition method are all good catalyst synthesis methods. Ultrasonic-assisted and MOF-assisted strategies also greatly improve the performance of catalysts. (5) The catalytic mechanism is the core of catalytic reaction research. Mo-based catalysts for the synthesis of higher alcohols from syngas require both CO dissociation and CO insertion steps, making the reaction process extremely complex. The currently accepted mechanism is the CO hydrogen-assisted dissociation pathway: first, adsorbed CO forms an alkoxide intermediate CHO under the action of H; some CHO undergoes CO bond cleavage to form alkyl species while others insert into adsorbed alkyl species to form carbon chain growth alkoxide intermediates which eventually hydrogenate to form higher alcohols. In addition, some authors suggest that short-chain alcohols undergo aldol condensation to form higher alcohols. The process of HAS is complex and existing characterization techniques are limited. The structure and reaction mechanism of Mo-based catalyst active centers are still unclear. Designing and developing highly active, selective, stable and economical catalysts remains a major issue for industrialization of syngas-to-higher-alcohol production. Future research should focus on improving and enriching characterization techniques and preparation methods to clarify the catalytically active phase and provide reliable evidence for clarifying the catalytic mechanism and designing catalysts in order to achieve controllable construction of active centers at an atomic level and lay a solid theoretical foundation for industrialization of syngas-to-higher-alcohol production. coredata.dc:description: The energy and environmental crises are becoming increasingly severe. Syngas, derived from coal, oil, biomass and other materials as an important platform for the conversion of matter and energy, can converted to the higher alcohols. Higher alcohols are important industrial raw materials and transportation fuels. Therefore, the synthesis of higher alcohols from syngas can effectively alleviate the energy and environmental crises. Despite decades of research, it is regrettable that the syngas to higher alcohols is still in the experimental research stage and has not yet been industrialized. This review comprehensively introduces the current status and progress of Mo-based catalysts for the syngas to higher alcohols. It is divided into three parts: MoS2, Mo2C and other Mo-based catalysts (MoOx, MoP, Mo2N and MoSe2) applied in the syngas to higher alcohols. Each part includes the promoters (alkaline promoters and transition metal promoters), active phase of catalysts, support, the preparation method and catalytic mechanism. The structure-activity relationship of catalysts, catalyst preparation and catalytic mechanism are emphasized to highlight the recent progress and challenges of Mo-based catalysts. The purpose of this review is to provide a comprehensive summary of Mo-based catalysts for the syngas to higher alcohols to provide a reference for the design, development and future perspective of Mo-based catalysts.
